headline: Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky: The comedian who became a wartime leader

annotations.paragraph: BBC News
annotations.reason: This is a source attribution and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Volodymyr Oleksandrovych Zelensky was a comedian with no political experience when he announced that he would be running in Ukraine's 2019 presidential election.
annotations.reason: This provides essential background on Zelensky's unexpected political rise.

annotations.paragraph: Six years later, he is an embattled wartime leader navigating a huge geopolitical upheaval as Donald Trump brings to an end years of strong American support for Ukraine.
annotations.reason: This updates the reader on Zelensky's current role and the geopolitical context.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky has been a symbol of Ukrainian defiance against Russian aggression. Slava Ukraini, or Glory to Ukraine, has been his battle cry since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on 24 February 2022.
annotations.reason: This highlights Zelensky's symbolic role and provides context on the conflict.

annotations.paragraph: Much of the world rallied behind him - he received several standing ovations after his address to the US Congress asking for American support.
annotations.reason: This illustrates international support for Zelensky and his efforts to secure aid.

annotations.paragraph: But just three years later, he finds himself in uncertain territory, with US President Donald Trump calling him a dictator and the US siding with Russia in votes at the UN to mark the third anniversary of the Ukraine war.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides new facts about Zelensky's current political challenges and international relations.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky's trip to Washington at the end of February, during which he was expected to sign an agreement on sharing his country's mineral resources with the US, ended in acrimony. He was told to leave the White House after an angry exchange with Trump and his vice-president, JD Vance.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific details about a significant diplomatic incident involving Zelensky.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky's arrival on the political scene was a case of life imitating art.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a vague generalization without specific information.

annotations.paragraph: Ironically, Zelensky's most celebrated role as a comic actor was playing a school teacher who was catapulted into the presidency on the TV series, Servant of the People.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Zelensky's background relevant to his political career.

annotations.paragraph: Cut to real life, and his election candidacy, aged 41, was initially seen by some as a joke - his political party is even called Servant of the People.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives context about the initial public perception of Zelensky's political career.

annotations.paragraph: But he won with a landslide 73% of the vote, promising to fight corruption and bring peace in the east of Ukraine.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about Zelensky's election victory and campaign promises.

annotations.paragraph: Sceptics feared Zelensky would turn out to be a puppet leader, controlled by oligarch Ihor Kolomoisky who backed his campaign and had been under investigation for fraud and money laundering.
annotations.reason: Offers relevant background on concerns about Zelensky's independence and ties to an oligarch.

annotations.paragraph: But Zelensky proved to be more independent than his doubters thought, and the anti-corruption drive by his administration has had some success.
annotations.reason: Directly addresses Zelensky's independence and achievements in anti-corruption efforts.

annotations.paragraph: Many Ukrainians also viewed Zelensky's rhetoric on the conflict in the eastern Donbas region and relations with Russia as too timid, says communications consultant Yaryna Klyuchkovska.
annotations.reason: Provides insight into public perception of Zelensky's approach to the conflict and Russia.

annotations.paragraph: As the drumbeat of war grew louder, Zelensky continued to emphasise his hopes for a diplomatic solution, even while Ukraine was reporting a rapid increase in ceasefire violations along the front line.
annotations.reason: Describes Zelensky's stance on diplomacy amid escalating tensions, relevant to his wartime leadership.

annotations.paragraph: His attempts to negotiate with Russia had only limited success.
annotations.reason: This provides context on Zelensky's diplomatic efforts with Russia.

annotations.paragraph: There were prisoner exchanges and moves towards implementing parts of a peace process, known as the Minsk agreements, but no breakthrough. Throughout 2020 his approval rating steadily fell.
annotations.reason: This gives specific details about the peace process and Zelensky's approval ratings.

annotations.paragraph: There was a notable shift in tone at the Munich Security Conference in February 2022, when Zelensky laid bare the threat his country was facing, and accused the West of appeasing a resurgent Russia.
annotations.reason: This highlights a significant moment in Zelensky's leadership and international relations.

annotations.paragraph: No Ukrainian leader had spoken so bluntly to the West before, according to Ms Klyuchkovska.
annotations.reason: This provides context on the uniqueness of Zelensky's approach.

annotations.paragraph: Then, on 24 February 2022 - just hours before Russia first began bombarding Ukraine's cities - came a key moment.
annotations.reason: This sets the stage for a pivotal event in the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: In a sober address posted on social media, speaking partly in Russian, Zelensky said he had tried to call Vladimir Putin to avert a war, and had been met by silence.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on Zelensky's efforts to prevent war and his communication with Putin.

annotations.paragraph: The two countries didn't need a war, he said, but if Ukrainians came under attack they would defend themselves.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contributes Zelensky's stance on the conflict and Ukraine's defensive position.

annotations.paragraph: "When you attack us you will see our faces - not our backs, but our faces."
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes Ukraine's resolve and determination to face the conflict.

annotations.paragraph: For his next broadcast after Russia had invaded, he wore military fatigues, reflecting the country's David-versus-Goliath struggle.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides narrative progression and symbolism of Zelensky's leadership during the invasion.

annotations.paragraph: That evening he made another address, warning Western leaders that if they did not help, tomorrow "war will knock on your doors".
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights Zelensky's appeal to Western leaders for support, adding to the narrative of international involvement.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky's nightly video addresses became a source of hope and comfort for millions of Ukrainians during the ongoing fighting. His ability to connect was perhaps most evident when he posted a defiant video of himself with several top advisers in Kyiv, after Russia falsely claimed he had fled the capital.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific examples of Zelensky's leadership and communication during the war.

annotations.paragraph: "We are here," he repeated. "We are in Kyiv. We are protecting Ukraine."
annotations.reason: This quote directly illustrates Zelensky's defiance and leadership.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky quickly became a national figurehead, with a high of 90% approval ratings in the immediate aftermath of the invasion.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides factual information about Zelensky's popularity and leadership status.

annotations.paragraph: The war has understandably taken an emotional toll on Zelensky's family. His wife, Olena Zelenska, and their two children spent months living in secret locations for their own safety. The four have spent very little time together since the start of the conflict.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers personal context about the impact of the war on Zelensky's family.

annotations.paragraph: Further afield, Zelensky has seen it as his mission to galvanise support for Ukraine, leaning on his western allies to provide aid and fast-track his country's membership of Nato.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Zelensky's international efforts and strategic goals.

annotations.paragraph: In between visits to the front line, he has spoken with foreign leaders to lobby support and attended conferences across the globe, pleading for help.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on Zelensky's diplomatic efforts during the war.

annotations.paragraph: One of the most striking and enduring images from the early months of the war was his visit in April 2022 to the outer Kyiv suburb town of Bucha - where Russian troops are suspected of committing hundreds of war crimes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives context about a significant event involving Zelensky during the war.

annotations.paragraph: His first foreign trip after the invasion came in December 2022 when he went to the US to visit then-President Joe Biden - unsurprising given Washington had been Kyiv's largest backer.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about Zelensky's diplomatic actions and support from the US.

annotations.paragraph: During that trip, Zelensky received several standing ovations when he addressed Congress and told them: "Against all odds... Ukraine is alive and kicking" and will "never surrender".
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a significant quote from Zelensky that highlights his leadership and resolve.

annotations.paragraph: Biden also promised further support to Ukraine, saying the American people were prepared to "have us stand up to bullies".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on the US's commitment to supporting Ukraine, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: But Zelensky has cut a frustrated figure at times over the speed at which he has received western support - as well as the reluctance to approve the use of some weapons on the front line.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into Zelensky's challenges with Western support, relevant to his role as a wartime leader.

annotations.paragraph: Even in the first few months of the conflict, it was clear there would be pushback from some Republican Party quarters over how much support the US should give.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context on US political dynamics affecting support for Ukraine, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Three years on, and with a different president in the White House, there appears to be a deepening rift between the two countries.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides narrative progression about the evolving relationship between Ukraine and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky has long maintained that talks about Ukraine's future should be conducted with Ukraine at the table. But the Americans have instead met with Russian officials to discuss the war - and Ukraine wasn't there.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights a significant diplomatic issue involving Zelensky, relevant to his leadership challenges.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky has accused the US of helping Putin to "break out of years of isolation" and said Donald Trump lives in a "Russian disinformation space".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct quotes from Zelensky, illustrating his stance and criticisms, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Meanwhile, Trump has turned his ire on Zelensky, calling him a "dictator" - echoing Russia's claims - and criticising the fact that Ukraine has not held an election since 2019.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about external criticism of Zelensky, which is pertinent to his role as a wartime leader.

annotations.paragraph: A vote was scheduled for May 2024, but it was suspended because Ukraine has been under martial law since the invasion began, a decision that was broadly backed by the opposition and the Ukrainian population.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers important context about the political situation in Ukraine under Zelensky's leadership.

annotations.paragraph: Zelensky has suggested he would be willing to resign as leader in return for Ukraine's membership of Nato.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides significant information about Zelensky's stance and potential political strategy.

annotations.paragraph: Trump also took aim at Zelensky's approval rating. It is true that his popularity has dipped over the years, but as Yaryna Klyuchkovska noted, for someone who started with such a high approval rating - the only way was down.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Zelensky's approval rating, which is relevant to understanding his current political standing.

annotations.paragraph: Even so, while polling is limited in Ukraine because millions have fled and Russia occupies about a fifth of the country, a recent survey suggested Zelensky still has the support of 57% of Ukrainians.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides current polling data, which is relevant to assessing Zelensky's support as a leader.

annotations.paragraph: Russia's war on Ukraine has lasted far longer than Moscow intended - Putin had hoped to take Ukraine within a matter of days of launching what it calls its "special military operation".
annotations.reason: Provides context on the duration and initial expectations of the conflict.

annotations.paragraph: Three years since the start of the invasion, and while Russia continues to make territorial gains, Ukraine has managed to slow the advance and even mount a counter-offensive inside Russia itself.
annotations.reason: Offers an update on the current state of the conflict and Ukraine's military actions.

annotations.paragraph: Ukraine's future is still uncertain, but Zelensky remains defiant in the face of Russian aggression.
annotations.reason: Comments on Zelensky's stance and the ongoing uncertainty, relevant to his leadership role.
